chapter.htmlHeader: What is natural family planning?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Natural family planning is a method of birth control where a woman monitors and records different fertility indicators during her menstrual cycle to determine when she is least (or most) fertile.
  • There are two different types of natural family planning methods:
    • Fertility awareness methods (FAM).
    • The lactational amenorrhoea method (LAM).
  • Natural family planning methods can be used to:
    • Avoid pregnancy, by prompting a change in sexual behaviour during the woman's fertile time. This may include:
      • Abstaining from vaginal intercourse.
      • Using a barrier method of contraception, for example condoms.
      • Using the withdrawal method (coitus interruptus). This is the least effective contraceptive method, and is therefore not recommended.
[FPA, 2014]

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What do fertility awareness methods of contraception involve?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Fertility awareness methods involve identifying when a woman is least (or most) fertile by:
    • Monitoring and recording fertility signs such as:
      • Cervical secretions — the woman can look and feel for cervical secretions. An increase in volume of cervical secretions which are wet, slippery, and clear indicates that ovulation is approaching. 
      • Changes in the cervix — the woman can palpate the cervix. The fertile window starts at the first sign of the cervix changing from being low and firm, to the cervix being high and soft. 
      • Basal body temperature — the woman can monitor her resting body temperature every day. A slight rise in temperature that persists for 3 days indicates that the fertile time has ended. 
      • The menstrual cycle and the fertile period (calendar day method) — this involves calculating the length of the menstrual cycle (over a minimum of 12 cycles) and using this to estimate the time of ovulation and the fertile days of the menstrual cycle.
    • Using fertility monitoring devices to monitor hormonal changes in the body.
      • Computerized monitoring devices are available which use urine dipsticks to follow changes of hormone concentrations.
      • Note: Dipstick tests for luteinizing hormone and ovulation predictor kits are also available and are intended to help women conceive. However, they are not effective as a natural family planning method.
  • The fertile time is more accurately estimated by a combination of methods than by any single method.

[Hatcher et al, 1997; FPA, 2014; FSRH, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: The menstrual cycle and the fertile period
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The menstrual cycle is defined as the time from the first day of a period (first day of bleeding) up to the day before the start of the next period.
  • Women's menstrual cycles vary in length.
    • The average length is around 28 days, however, longer or shorter cycles are normal [Pyper and Knight, 2001]. 
    • Regardless of the length of the cycle, ovulation will usually occur 10 to 16 days before the start of the next menstrual cycle.
  • The fertile time lasts for around 8 to 9 days of each menstrual cycle.
    • The most fertile time is from about 7 days before ovulation until about 2 days after ovulation. This is because sperm in a woman's reproductive tract can remain viable for up to 7 days. The unfertilized egg is viable for about 24 hours, but occasionally more than one egg is released at ovulation (within 24 hours of the first egg being released).
  • During the fertile time, the chances of becoming pregnant are about 10–33% [Wilcox et al, 1995].
    • However, the fertile period can be unpredictable, and although the risk of pregnancy in the first 3 days of the cycle is negligible, there is no time in the menstrual cycle when the risk of pregnancy is zero. Estimates of 'safe' days are particularly imprecise when the menstrual cycle is irregular or there is uncertainty about the date of the last menstrual period [FSRH, 2015].

[FPA, 2014]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What does the lactational amenorrhea method of contraception involve?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The lactational amenorrhoea method involves breastfeeding after childbirth to prevent pregnancy.
  • Breastfeeding delays the return of ovulation by disrupting gonadotrophin release, but the mechanism is uncertain.
  • Women can use the lactational amenorrhoea method for the first 6 months after giving birth, provided that all the following conditions are met:
    • Complete amenorrhoea.
    • Fully or very nearly fully breastfeeding 
      • A woman is no longer fully, or nearly fully breastfeeding, if the baby is getting less than 85% of its feeds as breast milk.
    • Six months or less since the birth of the baby.

[Tommaselli et al, 2000; FPA, 2014; FSRH, 2015]
